original_title: Sri Lankan banking sector drag down market as investors wait for clarity on debt restructuring
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s shares closed at a one-week low mainly due to the banking and financial industry dragging it down, as investors continue to adopt a wait-and-see approach until clear directions are given on domestic debt restructuring, an analyst said.
The main All Share Price Index (ASPI) was down 0.13 percent, or 12.23 points, to 9,279.19.
“Investors are waiting for clear direction after the IMF comments regarding the local debt restructuring,” the analyst said.
Top losers during trade were Citizens Development Finance, Vallibel One, and LOLC.
Creditors had scheduled debt talks on April 20; however, no news has surfaced regarding the debt talk, while the IMF deal is scheduled to be presented to Parliament on April 25th.
“The debt restructuring fear has caused the banking sector shares to go down, which is dragging the market for the last few days.”

The market generated a turnover of 933 million rupees, below the daily average of 1.7 billion rupees. The majority of the revenue generated came from the Capital Goods index, generating 242 million rupees, and the Material Industry index, generating 205 million rupees.
“The more a wait-and-see approach is adopted, the lower the turnover gets,” the analyst said.

Sri Lanka’s Governor, Nandalal Weerasinghe, stated that the country would not restructure Treasury bills outside of central bank holdings and would engage with major T-bond holders for voluntary ‘optimization.’
The most liquid index, S&P SL20, was up 0.29 percent, or 7.79 points, to 2,718.22.

There was a net foreign inflow of 143 million rupees, the highest inflow recorded since April 18, bringing the total net foreign outflow for the year so far to 2.6 billion rupees, and a majority of the inflow came from Tokyo Cement (Non Voting). (Colombo/April20/2023)
